comments.commentBody: Mike, I think the answer to the difference between lefties and righties is basic beliefs and social orientation.  It comes out in the long run.

How can ANY liberal be unable to imagine that people think differently from them, when its become impossible for their party to have even a prayer of controlling Congress? The shock was not that Hillary could lose, but that an narcissitic, unreflective, and completely inexperienced bully could beat her.
While I think its reprehensible if someone in your position can be fired for conservative views, you have to be old enough to know that we've tried these "moderate tax and regulation policies" repeatedly since the 1980s, and whatever growth they cause has not redounded to working people. What would give you the slightest reason to believe an even more radical version of the same thing (more radical given no possible effective opposition from Democrats) will be any different this time?

When Immanuel Kant wrote his essay on the question "What is Enlightenment?" he posited that enlightenment would happen if there were a totally free exchange of ideas for everyone 'as a scholar', independent from what the person's duties were in the outside world. We have not yet reached a state where such free exchange of ideas is possible. Generally speaking, the conservatives all too often don't want to follow the rules of 'scholarly discourse' because they are too sure of what they believe. On the other hand, if you were to utter overly liberal ideas in a business environment (even if it were entirely outside of the workplace), your chances of surviving in that world would be minimal. There are very uneven power distributions between adherents of liberal and less liberal views, and we have not even advanced to a point of liberty which was envisioned in the 18th century.

To obtain a stronger voice for conservatives in academic, all we'd need is more thoughtful conservatives. They would be quite welcome in the academy, and most university presidents would love them since they could extol them when they beg from wealthy alumni. So, Mr. Kristof, if you want more diversity in academia, why don't you exhort conservatives to study harder and then pursue an academic career that pays way less than the business world. We'd have a more balanced intellectual life in a jiffy.

"...conservatives all too often don't want to follow the rules of 'scholarly discourse'

They would've loved to had you stopped shaming and PC'ing them.

E.g., can you 'scholarly' reason with a racist without calling her names and shaming? If you do, then she might be able to discuss your views of gay rights with an open mind. So, a dialogue would ensue.

Though i don't hold my breath. I don't see the required level of open-mindedness in our academia, especially in humanities.

I am pleased to see that at least some of my fellow liberals have recognized the wake-up call delivered by Trump's unpresidented victory (pun intended). I notice that the comments focus on the more outrageous positions taken by conservatives and religionists, but we push some pretty controversial ideas too. While it is satisfying to preach to the choir, and being in the choir is pretty satisfying, we end up being stunned when the world doesn't fit our measurements. I don't think our children's minds will be poisoned by hearing honest presentation of right wing ideas, or at least honest debate. Listening is the key to critical thinking. I, for one don't want our universities to produce cookie-cutter thinking. Listen more. Compare and contrast. There is a larger world outside academia.

WP:

You're not a bad spinner yourself. There was no balanced rendering of events by Obama and Clinton in 2012 until AFTER the election, yet they were told the truth explicitly by people on the ground in Benghazi from almost the beginning.

When it happened, I condemned Romney in this forum for his public outrage that the truth wasn't being told by the administration; and when it became evident that we'd all been played for political reasons, I laughed and shrugged as well in this forum -- it was too late to affect the election.

Trump won in the Electoral College because of Mrs. Clinton's mistake of not campaigning in the upper Midwest and PA, believing that she had most of those battleground states sewn up. By such errors of political judgment does a candidate amass a popular vote plurality of 2.6 millions and STILL watches cabinet picks being made on Fifth Ave. and not in Chappaqua.

Gotta say, though: for eight years I've had my issues with Barack Obama's policies (not the man); but I never once questioned his legitimacy, which is all Democrats seem able to do with Trump.

I think it might not be a bad idea to consider voting with your consumer dollar. If you choose to bank with Wells Fargo you can always choose to stop banking with them. There are lots of other banks out there.

If you have grown skeptical of the business of banking of general, consider joining a local credit union. For the majority of us there is almost nothing a bank can do that a credit union cannot.

We can and should expect the government overseers of the financial industry to hold Wells Fargo and other banks that cheat accountable to the law. But if we really want to punish these companies there is no single more effective way for us to do so than to simply stop giving them our business. After all, it is our business that they live with and die without.

So, William...are you implying our country would be better off with HRC as POTUS because she is so trustworthy he and ethical?

You've been drinking some serious cool-Aid, my friend.

As a previous system admin I was always curious I knew I owed Wells Fargo but I was working for a third party temp agency so I typed my  name in the system and was surprised and old account they I owed them  about $150. So I went to the branch they seen I had a previous account looked it over and open up a checking and savings account now I could do Banking  or America or  Chase  .  As what brought me to this if you can create a  dummy which they have what's stoping someone from hiding money in millions of accounts, nothing. Just like any job when you snoop too much you let  get go while in San Diego on vacation lol.

I enjoyed the retronyms. I had adios before ADIUEU, but additional crosses straightened me out. By the way, I looked back and realized my spellchecker had changed retronyms to restrooms. That made me giggle (64 going on 13?).

My grandpa and namesake always had a paper package of black licorice in his overall pocket. He would share with us. I noticed his had a much stronger flavor than the licorice I'd eaten before. That type of licorice brings back memories of grandpa.

I'm sure grandpa's farm would be called organic today. I loved going there.

Thanks for bringing back good memories.
The problem is these insidious arbitration clauses are everywhere and it is often impossible to sue and get your day in court
There is a legal concept called piercing the corporate veil.  It needs to be activated far more.
Unfortunately, with our extremely unethical president elect there will be nowhere to move within the 50 states

After seeing General ! Flynn's tweet, I'm convinced: he is mad and a danger to society. But Flynn is only a tool. Trump is very different. He has no feelings for other people and no interest in truth. "Lying" doesn't capture it; a liar says something known to be true, but Trump doesn't care whether it's true or not as long as it's to his advantage. Remember, he is not just a con-man, he is a big-money professional con-man (professional: it's how he makes his living; documentation is found in the N. Y. Times and the Washington Post). That means if you believe anything he says, you're being conned.

Is this paranoid? No, the evidence is right out in public. LIsten to Trump's speeches, and if you reject his public speaking, read about what he says in his business as reported by his associates. Truth is at most an obstacle to be overcome, and often not even that.
Correction!  "a liar says something known NOT to be true"--very sorry!

"We want to be inclusive of people who don't look like us - as long as the think like us."

BINGO!

I have been writing that in these comments for 10 years only to receive the wrath of some egotistical, holier-than-thou, hypocritical liberal readers.

Thank you, Kristof. But you only expose the tip of the iceberg. Much of the hysteria is from fabricated accusations of conservatives. They paint all people who voted for Trump as racists and morally inferior to themselves.

I feel sorry for the students who supported Trump or supported some of his ideas who are now persecuted by other students, faculty, and administrators.

This is a great essay. However. I have to disagree with the statement that "the mainstream news media can’t do a thing" to deal with the fact that millions of Americans are so willing to accept baseless conspiracy theories as political facts. Certainly, neither the media nor almost anyone else, can reason with these people. But what the media can do is to help demonstrate that the Republican politicians and conservative movements who traffic in these conspiracy theories or fail to firmly reject them are unacceptable in our political system.

Trump, of course, is the most obvious example of the media's failure on this front. By any reasonable standard, Trump's trafficking in false conspiracy theories, along with his bigotry and complete lack of policy knowledge, made him completely unqualified to be President. Yet the media treated him as a legitimate candidate and ridiculously portrayed Clinton as somehow less honest than Trump. This was an epic failure, but far from the only. The reality is that most of today's Republican Party peddles in falsehoods and conspiracy theories in order to rile up the type of people who get their "news" from Breitbart, Fox, and other organs of misinformation. It is incumbent on our media to call out such outrageous behavior out for what it should be considered - disqualifying for elected positions in a democracy that we have little time left to save from utter destruction by conservatives.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive/

Professional news needs to present itself to the public. It first needs to dis-aggregate the term "media" so as to correctly lay entertainment on one side and reporting, analysis, and considered opinon on the other side. It needs to explain that professional journalists are specialists and that their organizations invest heavily in each story. It needs to contrast this with the world of non-specialist opinionators -- of which I, for example, am playing a small role here -- and the various venues in which they present themselves.  The other side of the media -- entertainment -- needs to clean up its act and stop presenting a fictitious world of conspiracies, slaughterers, rapists and war mongers; no less than the whole cast of repugnant stereotypes depicting class, race, religion -- you name it.  With consolidations in "media" e.g. Fox, NBC/Comcast etc. I'd have a hard time believing that the profit difference would be so great as not to pursue this.
Correction!  "a liar says something known NOT to be true"--very sorry!

At a campus where both politically conservative and liberal views are expressed, as well as views on religion openly expressed and embraced, I think that grouping conservatives and evangelicals together is one problem here. Evangelical does not necessarily mean conservative. And religious does not necessarily mean evangelical. While there is a core of truth to the argument here, I do think that part of the problem is that the left has ceded religion to the right. Both in academia and elsewhere, listening to people of faith and helping our students realize that "faith" does not necessarily mean an embrace of racism and misogyny could go a long way toward helping the conversation.  While I agree that an overwhelmingly "left" academia has serious shortcomings, might it be part of the problem that the right in the United States of America has come to stand for things that are ideologically inconsistent and problematic? e.g. condemning abortion while embracing gun rights, or cuts to aid for poor children and families.  When academics are trained to make ideologically consistent arguments, it's hard to embrace rejecting refugees, cutting health care, and Christianity in the same breath.  As an academic and Christian, I find the positions to be untenable,and while I might very well support or at least be sympathetic to, an ideologically consistent conservatism - I am horrified at the anti-immigrant, pro-gun, Islamophobic rhetoric that has taken over our Republican party.
Thank you, Jen.  Very well stated.  We have become a society of "labels" and an amorphous grouping of diverse people into one group or another does everyone a disservice.
Everyone should have written a will by age 59, even if they have good reason to think they'll live to 100.  (DAISNAID:  Do as I say, not as I do.)

As an economist with his name on a few textbooks, Krugman ought to know better than to over-simplify that it's about fast food and what his upper west side neighbors think about the white working class. It's about the winners and losers in the comparative advantages of international trade, and policy considerations needed for dealing with the larger economic adjustments.

And, no, I don't mean "losers" in the pejorative sense nor "winners" in the morally superior sense. The losers are people who lose their jobs to overseas competition and/or factory automation, and winners are people who buy the marginally less expensive and/or higher quality goods. I'm sure there's a graph with lines that cross and arrows that show direction to prove this point. Something to do with marginal something or other.

The fact that this divide between winners and losers exists in one way or another in countries across the globe speaks to the larger issue; it's not just the white working class in the American Great Lakes region. Policy makers--the elite?--haven't "made" policies that effectively address the dislocations that are the flip side of all the good stuff that comes from trade. Not in Europe, not in Japan, not in China, not in the United States.

I'm sure right-winger nationalists in France who used to have better jobs like eating food that the liberal French elite look down on. And, yes, I'm sure whatever it is ... it's better than what's served at Carl's Junior.

"These fake-religious organizations are essentially scam artists pretending to own morality" indeed, but I would think twice, thrice, and more before justifying lying because the recipient of the lie is a hypocrite, or has no morality, or any reason.

"And if a scholar happens to have conservative views, in my experience, they are welcomed, provided their scholarship merits it."

This lie is fat as lard.

People have lost their jobs for honestly reporting findings of their research on IQ disparities. Murray and Herrenstein have been vilified by academia for a solid and sound research. Other scholars of variance in human intelligence have been marginalized.

It's practically impossible to get a comparative study of human intelligence through an IRB.

Common on now, a professor was forced to resign for saying that Halloween is just Halloween. Meritorious scholarship? More like medieval witch-hunt.
Richard, you should be a political writing instructor, as you write well and spin even better, or anyway very thoroughly.

I'm a retired psychology professor and would like to defend my profession against charges of liberal bias. To begin, people should stop using liberal or conservative since there are no consistent definitions of either term. We can talk about people who vote for Democrats or Republicans; that is an objective categorization, and fairly stable. Most college professors vote for Democrats, but is that evidence of bias? Only two kinds of people vote for Republicans: rich people and dumb people. I do not believe that is a matter of opinion, but an objective fact--I also believe there are real facts in the world. Unless they have family money, college professors are almost never rich. Since a Ph.D. is a job requirement, they are rarely stupid--maybe no common sense, but not stupid since you can't get into a Ph.D. program without high GRE scores, and the GRE is a good intelligence test. Professors are trained to evaluate their ideas with evidence. To be a Republican, you have to believe things like tax cuts for rich people stimulate the economy or that your Party cares about blue collar workers that have no supporting evidence. It is thus not surprising that few professors vote for Republicans and wonder about people who do. That's not bias; that's dealing with the real world in objective terms. It's what we try to teach our students, and thankfully college degrees were the strongest predictor of political behavior in the recent election.

The thing is that is a very simplified way of looking at how tax cuts effect the economy, and wereas it is easy to put that down in a quickie paragraph, in college you have to actually analyze the entire context of those cuts to come to the conclusion that the tax cuts were beneficial, and would work in other different situations (like now where the current tax rates are substantially lower). This is the problem with starting out with a view that conservatives or Republicans are under-represented because their current views aren't on campus. Their views might not be on campus because every time those views get fully researched they turn out to just not be defensible (looking at you climate change skeptics).

Excuse me, but Reagan's tax cuts caused a huge increase in the federal deficit which Bush had to counter by raising taxes. Trickle down economics is a disproven theory that nobody should believe, because corporations use the money to benefit executives and shareholders, not workers (same with repatriating offshore money with tax amnesty.)  You don't say your background but my training was at the very conservative Univ. of Chicago Business School.  Many of the people I met there are exactly as you describe but on the right wing. The problem of not communicating certainly cuts both ways, and labelling people whose views may be complex is dismissing them not generating a dialogue.
I stand by my comment. Paul Krugman agrees.
If the person offering the Lexus is good enough (at conning), many people will.  Proof:  The millions who voted for the Con-Man of the Decade.

I can't blame Charles Blow for his whimsical way of pointing out the farce that is our President-Elect's pre-governing process (for lack of a better word). A few years (or maybe months) ago, a satirical episode written and produced by the "South Park" guys, SNL, any of the Comedy Central folk, could have brought down the house with absurd scenes of a Trump "transition" such as those we are watching on the nightly news. As I've commented before, they are not far from a Marx Brothers comedy in their parade of chaotic kookiness.

"Brought down the house" might be an ominous turn of phrase at this point, as the level of abuse of public trust we are witnessing is so potentially damaging to the public trust as to be Anti-American. Executives at these agencies such as the Dept. of Education, the Dept. of Energy and the EPA are not mere minions of the executive branch -- they cannot (at least not Constitutionally) conduct themselves in a manner contrary to the Congressional mandates pursuant to which those agencies were created.

Yet, several of Trump's appointments presume those institutions are nothing more than "Ministries of Presidential Special Interests," rather than systems for protecting property and rights which belong to all Americans. The naming of any person devoted to interests in direct opposition to the mandated public purpose of the U.S. agency they would head should offend every American as an attack on our hard-won Constitutional government.

Not so funny.

My apologies, Frank Bruni, you deserve proper credit for your spot-on survey of this absurd transition "process," for surviving that choppy trip in the dinghy to Mar-a-Lago, and for, among other things, managing to use the word "dinghy" in your portrait of the current nuttiness.
